entry.title: Open Data Barometer: now more than ever, we must strengthen open data initiatives across the world
entry.summary: The fourth edition of the Open Data Barometer finds that open data initiatives are stalling and may reinforce inequality. The ODI responds with three ways that governments can ensure open data benefits everyone

entry.title: Open letter to political parties: publish data on candidates and be open about how you use personal data
entry.summary: ODI CEO Jeni Tennison calls on political parties contesting the UK general election on 8 June to publish candidate data and be open about how they will use personal data in campaigns. It has been sent to parties with significant numbers of MPs or share of current opinion polls: the Conservative party, the Greens, the Labour party, the Liberal Democrats, the Scottish National Party and the UK Independence Party

entry.title: Open Contracting Innovation Challenge hosts its first international meetup in Kiev
entry.summary: The Open Contracting Innovation Challenge calls for applicants working with open data to strengthen the integrity and effectiveness of public procurement. In this blog, Innovation Consultant Tom Hunter recounts the first international meetup of the challenge held in Ukraine

entry.title: UK general election: how data can and should inform our decisions
African Open Data Leaders Network: an open call for outstanding government leaders
entry.summary: The African Open Data Leaders Network (AODLN) programme, held as part of this year's African Open Data Conference (AODC), is calling for exceptional African leaders of open data initiatives to take part in a two day programme

entry.title: Open call: Open Contracting Innovation Challenge
entry.summary: The Open Contracting Innovation Challenge calls for applicants working with open data to strengthen the integrity and effectiveness of public procurement for the chance to win a share of USD $60,000

entry.title: ‘Bring Open Data to Your School’: connecting teens with open data in Argentina
entry.summary: With access to more data about their communities, teenagers can use it to shape decisions and plan their futures. Supported by the ODI’s [mini-grants programme](https://theodi.org/news/odi-announces-winners-of-minigrants-to-support-governmentled-open-data-initiatives), the Argentine Government set out to empower young people with tools to find and compare information that could make a difference

entry.title: Briefing paper: UK government must support data sharing and open data in transport
entry.summary: To mark the launch of a [briefing paper](https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/media.ts.catapult/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/12092544/15460-TSC-Q1-Report-Document-Suite-single-pages.pdf) on data sharing and open data in transport, commissioned by Transport Systems Catapult, ODI COO Louise Burke outlines how government can support integrated, efficient and sustainable transport systems

entry.title: Data Pitch: a new Europe-wide data accelerator launches today
Sir Tim Berners-Lee, ODI Co-Founder, awarded prestigious Turing Award
entry.summary: Sir Tim Berners-Lee, ODI Co-founder, and Professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of Oxford, has today been awarded the 2016 [ACM A.M. Turing Award](http://amturing.acm.org/) by [The Association for Computing Machinery](http://www.acm.org/).

entry.title: Open call: Open Data Champions Programme – 22-24 May 2017
entry.summary: The Open Data Champions Programme calls for applicants working with open data in the public sector in Europe to take part in an exciting three-day programme of training and peer support in London

entry.title: Call for proposals: LMAO 😹
entry.summary: Where is the humour in data? In these meme-fuelled, data-overloaded, statistically skewed times, we are asking how, when and where can data be funny.

entry.title: The ODI’s international startup network comes to South-East Asia
When an international partnership works: growing open data startups in Mexico
entry.summary: Emma Truswell reports from Mexico City on how a partnership between the ODI, the Mexican government and an NGO has strengthened an international relationship, a government policy programme and a talented group of startups

entry.title: ODI Podcast: Open data stories from Argentina and Kenya
entry.summary: From public sector reform to building an initiative from the ground up, open data leaders from Argentina and Kenya share what's worked for their programmes, what hasn't and how we can improve equality of opportunity in data and tech

entry.title: Open Data Day: How to build a strong data economy
entry.summary: This [Open Day Day](http://opendataday.org/), ODI CEO [Jeni Tennison](https://theodi.org/team/jeni-tennison) shares what it means to build a strong data economy and why governments and businesses need to consider the roles of equity, ethics and engagement in creating one

entry.title: Guest post: African countries level playing field with oil and gold corporations
entry.summary: African countries are developing financial skills to stop some multinational corporations from taking advantage of their lack of know-how. Alex Starritt reports on teams from the Ivory Coast and Kenya tackling this problem using publicly available data

entry.title: How can open data portals become sustainable?
entry.summary: In a new [report](https://www.europeandataportal.eu/sites/default/files/edps3wp4sustainabilityrecommendations.pdf), commissioned by the [European Data Portal](https://www.europeandataportal.eu/), we highlight examples of best practice and set out recommendations for how open data portals can design processes that make them sustainable

entry.title: Open Inheritance Art project reveals 36,000 rarely seen private heritage artworks you can visit
entry.summary: Today, (16 February 2017) the [Open Inheritance Art](http://openiart.uk/) project, funded by the [Open Data Institute (ODI) Showcase](http://theodi.org/news/odi-showcase-winners-announced-for-our-summer-call), invites the public to discover and visit private collections of Britain’s most important cultural heritage artworks in a bid to increase access to art.

entry.title: Tribute to Hans Rosling
entry.summary: The work of Swedish data evangelist Hans Rosling has inspired many of us at the ODI, so here are some of our own reflections on how he’s influenced us and our mission.

entry.title: Guest post: How can gathering data help curb social exclusion?
entry.summary: ODI Associates Mar Santamaria Varas and Pablo Martinez Diez from [300.000 Km/s](http://www.300000kms.net/), discuss how analogue-to-digital tools can improve large-scale data collection processes in cities, helping to combat homelessness and social exclusion

entry.title: Invitation to tender: ODINE impact evaluation
entry.summary: The [Open Data Incubator for Europe](https://opendataincubator.eu/) (ODINE) is a 6-month incubator for open data entrepreneurs across Europe. The programme is funded with a €7.8m grant from the EU’s Horizon 2020 programme and managed by a number of consortium partners.

entry.title: Policy design patterns that help you use data to create impact
entry.summary: Policymakers sometimes struggle to see how data can be used to create impact in the world. They know that open data is relevant to the digital economy and building better public services but fail to see the many other ways that data can be used

entry.title: Guest post: Cities take to Yelp to tell their residents where not to eat
entry.summary: You can now compare restaurant reviews with hygiene data about the state of the kitchens, reports Alex Starritt, prompting dirty eateries to clean up their act

entry.title: Guest post: Empowering enterprises with linked data integration
entry.summary: Businesses now have access to more data than ever that can help inform their strategies. Milena Yankova shares how companies are adopting semantic web technology and linked data to get a holistic view of all the data they need

entry.title: Strengthening our legal data infrastructure
entry.summary: With the legal sector generating more and more data, the ODI and Thomson Reuters are exploring which datasets should be open, and how to improve data sharing in the sector. Following a discovery workshop, Amanda Smith invites the community to pitch in ahead of a white paper on strengthening our legal data infrastructure

entry.title: Wasting less and giving more: charities and funders unite with better data
entry.summary: Creator of tech-for-good venture Beehive explains how data made open by funders is helping thousands of charitable organisations to cut waste and raise funds, with tools and technologies emerging to help make the charitable sector more efficient

entry.title: The future of transport? Shared services built on data
entry.summary: Mobility as a Service has the power to change the way we travel. Ito World CEO Johan Herrlin shares what’s driving the movement forward, from smartphones to autonomous vehicles, and the critical role that data – especially open data – can play

entry.title: Open call for OpenActive advisory board applications
entry.summary: [Sport England](https://www.sportengland.org/) and the Open Data Institute are joining forces to help people find sport and physical activity opportunities with data

entry.title: Improving the resilience of cities using open data
entry.summary: By Jessica Weereratne

entry.title: Leading open data change in government: Seven success stories
entry.summary: By Kateryna Onyiliogwu

entry.title: Global gender goals: achieving local impact
entry.summary: Demand is growing for gender data and targeted solutions for challenges unique to women, men, girls or boys. Data, accountability and sustainable development expert Davis Adieno explains the challenges and opportunities of achieving gender equality through the Sustainable Development Goals

entry.title: Data infrastructure for investment banking
entry.summary: Investment banks provide financial products and services to clients such as corporations, high-net-worth individuals and governments. Typical services include raising capital, financial advice for mergers and acquisitions and risk management.

entry.title: Autumn Statement: UK must recognise the need to strengthen data infrastructure
entry.summary: Data is vital infrastructure for our society and a competitive advantage for a 21st century economy. It is an under-recognised piece of critical national infrastructure that needs government focus and support.

entry.title: Guest post: Inside the revolutionary sub-culture taking over government
entry.summary: Nothing has the transformative potential for civil servants' work as open data. Apolitical Editor Alex Starritt shares insights from leaders about their epiphany moment, and what made it impossible for them not to want to drive the movement forward

entry.title: Creating an open culture
entry.summary: As Franchise Network Coordinator at the Open Data Institute (ODI), creating a culture of openness is essential to my role in building the network of [ODI Nodes](https://theodi.org/nodes). Bringing together the diverse perspectives, skills and experiences from members across the world has provided a huge learning opportunity, both for myself and the ODI, and has helped us to succeed in establishing and progressing the network and its impact.

entry.title: Four new open data startups join ODI Startup accelerator programme
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute today welcomes four new startup organisations to its ODI Startup [accelerator programme](http://theodi.org/start-ups).

entry.title: Data is critical national infrastructure – let’s make it open and secure
entry.summary: The ODI calls on government to ensure that as it develops its digital strategy and the National Cybersecurity Strategy, it does not overlook the need for strong, effective and secure data infrastructure

entry.title: Open Data Awards 2016: open innovators from around the world
entry.summary: Yesterday, the Open Data Institute celebrated its third annual Open Data Awards at the British Film Institute in London, honouring innovation and excellence in open data across the world

entry.title: Open Oil: 'We look forward the day that $9tr of government procurement can be modelled and analysed'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with the team at Open Oil, one of the finalists for the Social Impact award.

entry.title: The ODI and Sport England join forces to get us all more active with data
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute and Sport England are announcing a new collaboration at the [ODI Summit](http://theodi.org/summit/2016) in London today. They will work together to improve and open up information about physical activity and sporting opportunities across England

entry.title: Open Data Nation: 'We use open data to find wasteful spending on public services'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we speak with the team at Open Data Nation, one of the finalists for the Business Award.

entry.title: Travel to Work: 'We need an evidence base to improve our transport infrastructure'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Charlene Adutwim, Senior Analyst within Organisational Intelligence at Essex County Council – one of Innovation Award finalists.

entry.title: Defra: 'Environment Agency laser mapping data has revealed lost Roman roads'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Tim Ashelford from Defra, finalist for the Publisher Award, about how they published over 10,000 open datasets in 12 months.

entry.title: Humanitarian Data Exchange: 'We want to surface data collected by mobiles in crises'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Sarah Telford from the UN’s Humanitarian Data Exchange, finalist for the Innovation Award.

entry.title: Louise Corti: 'I convince data owners to open it for the public good – I love my job'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Louise Corti, a finalist in the Women in data category, on her perspectives as an 'early adopter' and what it takes to persuade and train people to produce high-quality data for others to innovate with.

entry.title: GODAN: 'Agriculture data must be accessible for farmers at the local level'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with the team at GODAN, one of Social Impact Award finalists, on how they encourage data on agriculture and nutrition to be more accessible and usable worldwide

entry.title: Open Papers: 'To understand poverty and homelessness, we need to quantify it'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we speak with the team at 300.000 Km/s about their homelessness mapping project Open Papers, one of the finalists in the Innovation category.

entry.title: imin: 'We're enabling a new generation of digital health and fitness platforms'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with the team at tech-for-good company imin, a finalist in the Business category, about their work opening up physical activity data

entry.title: 360Giving: 'Our vision is for more informed UK grantmaking'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Katherine Duerden from 360Giving, a finalist in the Women in data category, about their work making grants from UK funders easier to search, explore and download.

entry.title: Exploring open data quality
entry.summary: To contribute to discussions around open data quality, the ODI has been working with [Experian](https://directory.theodi.org/members/AQ1298ST) to investigate quality in several UK Government open datasets. Here, ODI Associate Leigh Dodds introduces the project and its initial findings

entry.title: Four things you should know about open data quality
entry.summary: Better data can lead to better outcomes. But what do we mean by 'data quality'? ODI Associate Leigh Dodds, who is working with ODI Partner [Experian](https://directory.theodi.org/members/AQ1298ST) to explore data quality in UK open datasets, explains

entry.title: Giuseppe Sollazzo: 'Teaching medical researchers about data risks and opportunities is an exciting challenge'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Individual Champion award finalist Giuseppe Sollazzo about the many data projects he works on, from data analysis to advising ministers on standards and transparency.

entry.title: Data Mill North: 'Promoting open data is a bit like a sales job'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up Stephen Blackburn from Data Mill North, a finalist in the Publisher category, about how they promote open data and bring its benefits to communities in Leeds.

entry.title: Nikos Manouselis: 'In 10 years I want all food information to be interconnected'
entry.summary: With the [ODI Summit](http://theodi.org/summit/2016) less than a week away, we catch up with summit speaker and CEO of [Agroknow](http://www.agroknow.com/agroknow/), Nikos Manouselis, on what excites him about the future of open data and agriculture

entry.title: Niyi Abiri: 'Policymakers need geospatial data to target public resources'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Abiri Oluwatosin Niyi, co-founder and lead at cMapIT.com, one of the nominees in the Open Data Business Award category.

entry.title: Opening agriculture data for innovation: stories from local to global
entry.summary: When data related to agriculture and food is made open or shared more easily, more can be done by scientists, governments, NGOs and farmers to improve agriculture outcomes, say Bianca Wylie, Nikos Manouselis and Ashleigh Weeden

entry.title: Carey Anne Nadeau: 'We're bringing about the next great innovation in open data'
entry.summary: Carey Anne Nadeau has been nominated for an Open Data Business Award as part of the ODI's annual award ceremony. In the run-up to the awards, we talk to Carey Anne about Open Data Nation, a performance management company working with cities and counties to transform open data into actionable intelligence.

entry.title: Serah Njambi Rono on open data: 'Let's go back to basics'
entry.summary: With the 2016 Open Data Awards just around the corner, we catch up with Serah Njambi Rono, one of the award nominees for the Women in Data, in her capacity as developer advocate at Open Knowledge International.

entry.title: Guest post: What would the open data utopia actually look like?
entry.summary: We often hear of the smoother, safer and richer future that open data could help bring about. Apolitical Editor Alex Starritt speaks with some [open data leaders](http://theodi.org/blog/global-open-data-leaders-what-a-year-of-peer-learning-looks-like) about the steps we need to take to reach this promised land

entry.title: Achieving more with open data at data.parliament.uk
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute has conducted research to understand the user need for Parliamentary data, and the possibilities that adopting an open approach can bring to data.parliament.uk.

entry.title: ASEAN Data Startup Accelerator – open call for applicants
entry.summary: Are you a startup in the ASEAN region solving problems with data?

entry.title: Open Data Leaders Network: ODI grant announced to support a government-led open data project
entry.summary: Providing a grant of up to £6,500 to support an open data leader in solving problems with data and creating positive real-world impact

entry.title: The cultural chasm: why your strategy will fail without a data-literate organisation
entry.summary: Your organisation generates vast and growing reserves of data. But how do you ensure you capture its value? ODI Senior Learning Consultant Benjamin Cave sheds light on the importance of fostering data-literacy and culture change within organisations

entry.title: Better access for more impact: what open data can offer the third sector
entry.summary: Better data access and use for non-profit organisations has the potential to improve the services they offer. In this blog, two partners of [OpenGovIntelligence](http://www.opengovintelligence.eu/) explain their approach to making public data accessible and useful

entry.title: Where does your food come from? Provenance tells product stories
entry.summary: Consumers increasingly want to know where the products they buy have come from – whether designer clothes or food shopping. Being transparent has never been easier for brands, thanks to new software and platforms like Provenance.

entry.title: ODI Podcast: Food banks, data and social change
entry.summary: How can data analysis help us to understand and reduce food poverty? ODI Writer / Editor Anna Scott speaks with Andy Hamflett and Simon Raper, creators of the UK’s first dynamic visualisation tool for food poverty

entry.title: Open call for export-ready UK startups to win an expenses-paid investment trip to Mexico City
entry.summary: The [Open Data Institute](http://theodi.org/) invites your startup to apply for the Mexico-UK Data Enterprise competition, a bespoke one-week programme in Mexico for UK-based data startups

entry.title: Jeni Tennison calls on government to act as the model for best practice in data sharing
entry.summary: When questioned by the parliamentary committee tasked with the forthcoming [Digital Economy Bill](http://services.parliament.uk/bills/2016-17/digitaleconomy/documents.html) this week, ODI CEO Jeni Tennison called on government in its position of authority to 'act as a model for how to do data sharing well'

entry.title: World Food Day: Britain’s food habits – visualised
entry.summary: Have we fallen out of love with bread? This [World Food Day](http://www.wfp.org/worldfoodday) we show how visualising food data helped people understand consumption choices and trends over time

entry.title: Open Data Awards 2016: shortlists announced
ODI Art Associate Julie Freeman unveils a Naked Mole-Rat 'Eutopia' at Somerset House
entry.summary: ODI Art Associate Julie Freeman's latest exhibition 'A Naked Mole-Rat Eutopia' opens this week at Somerset House, featuring animations powered by live data from a naked mole-rat colony

entry.title: Reflections from the International Open Data Conference: open data has grown up
entry.summary: On the final day of [IODC](http://opendatacon.org/), Anna Scott reports on what was covered at the conference, and reflects on a shift from starry-eyed evangelism to reflective and forward-thinking analysis

entry.title: ODI and the Open Government Partnership launch challenge series in South Africa
entry.summary: The ODI are supporting the Open Government Partnership in launching the [Responsive Cities Challenge](http://challenge.responsivecities.org.za/), a challenge series in South Africa to help local governments tackle social issues through the innovative use of open data

entry.title: ODI announces winners of mini-grants to support government-led open data initiatives
entry.summary: The winners of the ODI's recent open call to support government-led open data initiatives through mini-grants have been announced. Get to know more about the winning projects and see what they have in store

entry.title: Open elections: lessons for open data from Burkina Faso and Zambia
entry.summary: We have just completed a [case study of the open elections project in Burkina Faso](http://theodi.org/case-study-burkina-fasos-open-elections), in partnership with the US-based election support organisation, IFES. As we were writing it, we were following an attempt in Zambia to release election results there openly and in real-time. Comparing the two led to some reflections on the need for an open data infrastructure for elections, which will frame our conversation at IODC this coming Thursday

entry.title: International Open Data Conference 2016: what the ODI has in store
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute will be running diverse sessions, joining panels and reporting at the [International Open Data Conference](http://opendatacon.org/) this week in Madrid

entry.title: New open data trainers to help Tanzania achieve Sustainable Development Goals
entry.summary: Last week a group of data experts from Tanzania became the first wave of new trainers to teach people across the country about the potential uses and benefits of open data. The ODI’s intensive, week-long [Train the Trainer course](https://theodi.org/courses/train-the-trainer) had previously only been run in the UK, but those involved in Tanzania’s growing open data movement enabled the ODI to run its first international session in Dar es Salaam in September 2016

entry.title: European Open Data Leaders Network: an open call for outstanding leaders – 22 November 2016
entry.summary: The European Open Data Leaders Network (ODLN) programme calls for exceptional European leaders working with open data to take part in a day of training and peer support

entry.title: Hunger, malnutrition and the value of openness
entry.summary: How can open data help to end global hunger? Our CEO Jeni Tennison reflects on her time at the [Global Open Data in Agriculture and Nutrition (GODAN) Summit](http://summit.godan.info/) in New York, and explores openness as a catalyst for innovation in agriculture and nutrition

entry.title: ODI Showcase – Winner’s Q&A: VacSeen
entry.summary: We chat with Partha S Bhattacharjee and Monika Solanki about their ideas behind winning ODI Showcase project Vacseen, and what the team has in store

entry.title: Using open data and volunteered geographic information for smart cities
The General Data Protection Regulation expands the definition of personal data
entry.summary: By Efrén Díaz Díaz

entry.title: ODI calls for future data pioneers to speak at ODI Summit
entry.summary: We are launching an open call for young people aged 16-30 to [share with us](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfDCsABmNZxqBSQ3rt9vNOZmtEhwPieuOap3bkyEULCYSnXJg/viewform) how they think data can solve a local or global problem. The winners will share their ideas on stage with Sirs Nigel Shadbolt and Tim Berners-Lee at the ODI Summit

entry.title: ODI Showcase – winner’s Q&A: Energy Sparks
entry.summary: We chat with Leigh Dodds about his ideas behind winning ODI Showcase project Energy Sparks, and what the team has in store

entry.title: ODI Showcase – winner’s Q&A: Great British Toilet Map
entry.summary: We chat with Gail Ramster about her ideas behind winning ODI Showcase project Great British Toilet Map, and what the team has in store

entry.title: ODI Showcase – winner’s Q&A: Open Inheritance Art
entry.summary: We chat with Jo Pugh about his ideas behind winning ODI Showcase project Open Inheritance Art, and what the team has in store

entry.title: Jeni Tennison OBE appointed ODI Chief Executive Officer
Three steps to becoming a data-literate leader
entry.summary: The web of data is growing fast, and leaders need to know how their organisation can adapt. This starts with being data literate – understanding data in relation to their organisation, how to interact with it and what impact it can have

entry.title: ODI Showcase 2016 – winners announced for our summer call
entry.summary: The winners for our ODI Showcase summer call 2016 have been selected. Meet some of the teams behind the projects, and find out what they have in store

entry.title: Open banking could mean better services for everyone
entry.summary: Open banking is about much more than an app. With emphasis on ensuring trust and privacy, the Open Banking Standard aims to free up banking data and enable better services. We have set up an [Open Banking Development Group](http://theodi.org/open-banking-development-group-join-today) to help achieve this

entry.title: Building best practices for sharing public sector data
entry.summary: ODI Associate Leigh Dodds looks at how the Share-PSI 2.0 project is collecting and sharing best practices around the publication of public sector information, a useful resource for anyone leading or contributing to an open data initiative

entry.title: Retelling the stories of displaced people in Nigeria with data
entry.summary: Years of conflict have displaced over 2.2 million people in Nigeria. Tired of hearing horrific news stories with nothing being done, Blaise Aboh used data visualisation to raise awareness and demand more open data from humanitarian groups

entry.title: How do we 'own' data?
entry.summary: We live in an age of data abundance. We produce data every day – as people, businesses, charities and governments – that might be used to generate valuable insights and services. Ellen Broad explores data ownership in this age of abundance

entry.title: Call for nominations: Open Data Awards 2016
entry.summary: The ODI opens its call for nominations for the Open Data Awards 2016 from pioneering individuals and businesses working with open data in the UK and worldwide

entry.title: Women in data: closing the data gap and convening equality groups in Asia
entry.summary: If we’re all working towards gender equality, shouldn’t we share and improve information? This question drove entrepreneur Jacqui Hocking to crowdsource and link equality communities in Asia, to minimise duplication and increase impact

entry.title: The ODI shows data infrastructure is growing, with £50m generated from data so far
entry.summary: The ODI and its network of startups, franchises and partners, have generated £50m from data since the ODI opened in December 2012, highlighting data’s ongoing value for the global economy

entry.title: We need to learn how to search the web of data
entry.summary: Search for the web of data is still in the portal era, but portals do not meet all user needs. Imagine a world where you could search for, find, understand, trust and use data as easily as you can for news. Peter Wells explores what's possible

entry.title: CMA announcement signals that UK can lead the world in banking
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute (ODI) welcomes the Competition and Markets Authority's final report, launched today: [making banks work harder for you](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/retail-banking-market-investigation-overview).

entry.title: Announcing GODAN Action: making open data work for agriculture and nutrition
entry.summary: The ODI is delighted to announce the launch of an exciting new project, [GODAN Action](http://www.godan.info/news/godan-action-enabling-practical-engagement-open-data-agriculture-and-nutrition).

entry.title: How to open your data in six easy steps
entry.summary: Do you have a raft of useful data you’re ready to open up for others to make use of, but don’t know where to start? Organisations like [Arup](http://theodi.org/open-enterprise-big-business-case-study-arup) and [Thomson Reuters](http://theodi.org/open-enterprise-big-business-case-study-thomson-reuters) have discovered huge benefits in opening their data, but it can be a daunting task. ODI Associate Leigh Dodds has broken down the process into six easy steps.

entry.title: ODI Queensland wins AU$400k funding to maximise open access to government data
entry.summary: Pioneer Node ODI Queensland has secured $400k from the government to help enable open access to government data. Alex Leon shares how this new partnership could help bridge the gap between open data commitment and action in Australia

entry.title: GODAN announces agriculture and nutrition open data challenge with $21,000 prize pot
entry.summary: Ahead of its summit in September, the Global Open Data for Agriculture and Nutrition network is looking for practical, data-driven solutions for specific challenges in agriculture and nutrition

entry.title: ODI submits implications of leaving the EU to UK Parliament Science and Tech Committee
entry.summary: From database rights to funding, access to public sector information to data portability, the ODI has submitted implications and opportunities of leaving the EU for science and technology, and reaffirmed the need to maintain data infrastructure

entry.title: You can now buy your own copy of Datopolis, the open data board game
entry.summary: Today the beta version of Datopolis, our open data board game, goes on sale via [Gamecrafter](https://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/datopolis) for two weeks. Its creators Ellen Broad and Jeni Tennison tell the story behind it, how it was made and what you can expect from buying your very own copy.

entry.title: ODI responds to consultation on improving the consumer landscape
entry.summary: As part of its aim to empower consumers to make wise decisions when purchasing goods and services, the UK Government has issued a [consultation](https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/improving-the-consumer-landscape-and-quicker-switching-call-for-evidence) on ways to improve consumer choice. In its call for evidence, the government highlighted a particular need to improve advice and representation, and make switching suppliers easier and less time-consuming across all sectors.

entry.title: 'From media to education, we're making the most out of data in Tanzania'
entry.summary: The open data movement is going from strength to strength in Tanzania. Joachim Mangilima reflects on recent progress made, and how inclusive data training for government and sector-specific groups has boosted initiatives in the country

entry.title: Peer learning helps Tanzania reach new ground with open data
entry.summary: When we introduced Tanzanian open data officials to their UK counterparts they shared home truths about problems, gaining new perspective and inspiration to engage users, communicate more and seek support from those who can help

entry.title: What is the vital data infrastructure for agriculture?
entry.summary: Announcing a public consultation on an Agriculture Sector Package for the Open Data Charter

entry.title: Forging stronger data infrastructure in Canada
entry.summary: The need for a strong data infrastructure increasingly influences how governments work, think and act. ODI Toronto's [Andi Argast](http://toronto.theodi.org/our-team/) is a technology strategist and facilitator, and here shares how Ontario is approaching policy around data infrastructure

entry.title: My week with the world’s open data leaders
entry.summary: With our current [open call](http://theodi.org/blog/open-data-leaders-network-open-call-2016) for government leaders to join the Open Data Leaders Network, former participant Aleksej Vyskub reflects on his week at the ODI and his new plans to change Ukrainian law and innovate with open data

entry.title: Comment: Pressure still needed to put mothers’ names on marriage certificates
entry.summary: As weddings get more weird and wonderful, why are marriage certificates in England and Wales still so outdated? Replacing marriage ‘books’ with an electronic register would allow more flexibility and stop mothers from being ‘airbrushed out of history’

entry.title: New Data as Culture exhibition 'Thinking Out Loud' explores the inner workings of code and craft
entry.summary: Featuring raves fuelled by computer algorithms, 'hacked' woollen jumpers and revived primitive Inca data storage, the new Data as Culture exhibition 'Thinking Out Loud' exposes how modern and traditional crafts are built with code

entry.title: Open Data Leaders Network: an open call for outstanding government leaders - 2016
entry.summary: The Open Data Leaders Network (ODLN) programme calls for exceptional global leaders of open data initiatives worldwide, to take part in its 6-month programme in 2016-17

entry.title: Guest post: 5 things I learned at the Open Data Leaders Network
entry.summary: With our [open call](http://theodi.org/blog/open-data-leaders-network-open-call-2016) for government leaders to join the Open Data Leaders Network launched today, former participant Pauline Riordan reflects on lessons she learned as part of the network, from creating a common language to outsourcing innovation

entry.title: Invitation to tender: Researcher for coordinating ‘Resilient cities’ discussion paper
entry.summary: Call for tenders by the Open Data Institute (ODI) as part of the Open Data for Development Network (OD4D).

entry.title: Open Data Leaders Network: ODI grants announced to support government-led open data projects
entry.summary: Providing three grants of up to £6,500 each to support Open Data Leaders solve problems with data and create positive real-world impact

entry.title: The open future of banking
entry.summary: By Gavin Starks and Peter Wells

entry.title: Data knows no boundaries
entry.summary: By Peter Wells and the [ODI Team](http://theodi.org/team)

entry.title: Comment blog: How can opening up pension data empower citizens and stimulate innovation?
entry.summary: By Will Lovegrove of pensionsync

entry.title: ODI Podcast: Apps for workplace wellbeing
entry.summary: Can a bot help you manage your stress levels at work? In this ODI Podcast, Martin Vowles speaks with ODI Editor Anna Scott about the ideas behind his software company Plexus, and the digital products it creates to support workplace wellbeing

entry.title: Open Data Leaders Network: lessons from Istanbul
entry.summary: After meeting Eurasian open data leaders last week, Flavia Munteanu reflects on the consensus to rethink open data as a top regional priority, advocate it as a service that citizens have a right to, and leverage success stories as a catalyst for change

entry.title: 7 services using open data and innovation that you (probably) already use
entry.summary: Open innovation and open data can seem like strange concepts, but they drive many of the apps, products and services we use daily. Here are seven of our favourites

entry.title: Transport Systems Catapult and the ODI announce a strategic partnership to develop transport data infrastructure
entry.summary: TSC and the ODI are exploring the data infrastructure and open standards needed to support transport innovation and bring about transition to 'intelligent mobility'

entry.title: How open data can support land use for the common good
entry.summary: Open data on land could be great for land-based enterprises, but most cannot easily access it. We need to get this data into the hands of people who can use it to improve the environment and people’s lives, says Tom Kenny

entry.title: Comment: Open data, crime and punishment – the perplexing pursuit of business rates
entry.summary: Since the recession in 2008, news of high-street businesses failing has not long been out of the headlines. Understanding the scale of the problem, and ultimately tackling it, requires data – data that many local authorities are not willing to release. "From the sublime to the ridiculous," Gavin Chait reflects on reasons given to him by 66 authorities in refusing his Freedom of Information requests, and warns of the harm being done to local economies. This is the first in our long-form series

entry.title: Introducing Bothan: a tool to bring your metrics to life and share them with the world
entry.summary: What more could you do with your metrics? Stuart Harrison from the ODI Labs team introduces [bothan.io](http://bothan.io/), a tool for anyone to store and share metrics or performance indicators as open data, with embeddable visualisations and a full JSON API

entry.title: 8 reasons to join Open Data in a Day
entry.summary: Open Data in a Day is the ODI’s flagship one-day course. Whether you're a total beginner or clued up on the basics of open data, Open Data in a Day will help you discover it, talk about it and use it for social, environmental and economic benefits

entry.title: One year on from the general election: what does the UK data landscape look like?
entry.summary: A year on from the UK general election, ODI Head of Policy Ellen Broad revisits last year's 'Open data roadmap for the UK' and reflects on what has been achieved, key challenges that remain and recommendations for strengthening our data infrastructure

entry.title: Consultation response on moving Land Registry operations to the private sector
entry.summary: In its [consultation response](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L-11245C6uBydZOBByOIMIh3cvDrttP39IGM1vMJXI/edit), the ODI stresses that core data assets are essential to our data infrastructure, and government should be creating healthy and open markets, not centralised monopolies

entry.title: Comment: What would an open data future look like?
entry.summary: This is the fourth in a blog series discussing how the future affects [data infrastructure](http://theodi.org/who-owns-our-data-infrastructure). The [first](http://theodi.org/blog/how-will-future-affect-data-infrastructure) describes why we are considering three potential data futures, the [second](http://theodi.org/blog/locked-down-data-future-infrastructure) explores the locked-down future, and the [third](http://theodi.org/blog/comment-paid-data-future) explores the paid future

entry.title: ODI Podcast: Editing out the gender gap on Wikipedia
entry.summary: ODI Writer / Editor Anna Scott speaks with Lucy Crompton-Reid, CEO of Wikimedia UK, about addressing gender bias and promoting women's participation in Wikipedia and other knowledge platforms

entry.title: Guest post: Why the BBC should make its recipes database open data
entry.summary: The BBC has announced that it is cutting its popular recipe service. Open data could be the key to retaining its value, says Andy Dickinson

entry.title: Guest post: How to visualise linked open data
entry.summary: Open data’s potential increases when datasets are linked, and transforming linked datasets into visualisations can extend positive impacts even more. ODI St Petersburg share how they built a tool to allow anyone to visualise linked, open data

entry.title: Introducing the Open Data Skills Framework
entry.summary: Having developed an Open Data Skills Framework to benchmark open data skills and manage learner journeys, the ODI is integrating the framework into its [courses](http://theodi.org/courses) and [Data Lexicon](https://docs.google.com/document/d/14PYnur8C7LUoz2VIelJbv5zqRbp0HiFu8ixcu0Co1xY/edit) for better guidance and clarity on open data skills

entry.title: Guest post: Tackling corruption by making data shareable
entry.summary: As world leaders gather in London for an [anti-corruption summit](https://www.gov.uk/government/topical-events/anti-corruption-summit-london-2016), Tharindi Hapuarachchi says our success in the fight will be determined by the effectiveness with which data is shared, in line with new research by the ODI and Thomson Reuters

entry.title: Guest post: Empowering citizens to contribute to a data commons
entry.summary: Imagine if we could safely contribute anonymised personal data to a commons for others to reuse. Tom Heath reflects on a project run with King's College London to explore how insights and benefits can be extended beyond the few to the many

entry.title: Google deep in trust issues around use of UK patient data
entry.summary: Google's DeepMind Health aims to improve patient care using data. But a leaked agreement with Royal Free NHS Trust has fuelled suspicions around how patient data is shared, exposing the need for greater transparency in data-sharing in healthcare

entry.title: Seven weird ways that data is used
entry.summary: Data doesn’t have to mean dry numbers, statistics and spreadsheets. When it’s opened or shared, it can be mashed up, presented and interpreted in a huge range of weird and wonderful ways

entry.title: Open Government Partnership celebrates open innovation in Africa
entry.summary: As diverse delegates gather in Cape Town this week for the OGP regional meeting, we reflect on open innovation, ODI projects and promising initiatives in the continent

entry.title: Out for the Count: bringing you fast local election results on 5 May
entry.summary: ODI Showcase project team Out for the Count are working to bring democratic transparency to the digital age – they will deliver the first open dataset of local election results as soon as possible after the votes are counted. Here’s how they plan to do it

entry.title: Comment: Banking will have its Uber moment only with continued action
entry.summary: [Open Banking Working Group](http://theodi.org/news/open-banking-working-group-terms-of-reference) member Louise Beaumont welcomes a trend that could do for finance what innovation did for taxis, with the Open Banking Standard and the rise of alternative finance paving the way for new markets and better products

entry.title: How to build the data infrastructure to tackle urban air pollution
entry.summary: Addressing urban air quality is a huge challenge, and strategies to regulate pollution are failing. What's lacking is data infrastructure to help monitor air pollution and build the shared understanding we need to find sustainable solutions, says Jamie Fawcett

entry.title: Open Data Leaders: ODI grants to support government-led open data projects
entry.summary: Providing four grants of up to £6,500 for government-led open data projects in developing countries that solve problems and create positive real-world impact

entry.title: LGA and ODI work together to improve local authority publishing standards
ODI Podcast: Open elections in Burkina Faso
entry.summary: In the first ODI Podcast, ODI Editor Anna Scott speaks with Malick Tapsoba of the Burkina Faso Open Data Initiative on transparency, how his team used open data to support democracy and lessons for other governments aspiring for open elections

entry.title: Environment Agency reaches its #opendefra target with latest water quality data release
entry.summary: With today’s water quality data release, EA has hit its target to release 1,500 datasets. We reflect on uses and benefits of EA open data, from flood defences to creating 3D worlds in Minecraft, and affirm how ‘going open’ has benefitted the agency itself

entry.title: Open Data Barometer: ODI releases key research as challenger countries gain pace
entry.summary: With the 2015 Open Data Barometer released today, the ODI reflects on global achievements and critical gaps, and publishes research on emerging trends and lessons on supporting open data initiatives for widespread positive impact

entry.title: ODI responds to UK Land Registry privatisation consultation
entry.summary: In response to the UK Government consultation on privatising the Land Registry, the ODI is seeking input from data users and has released new economic research exposing the risks that come with restricting core public sector data assets

entry.title: New research exposes risks in privatising the UK Land Registry and restricting its data
entry.summary: In light of new research commissioned by the ODI on the economic value of open versus closed data, Peter Wells reaffirms the benefits of making all Land Registry data open and unrestricted

entry.title: Guest post: Putting forgotten communities back on the map with open data
entry.summary: How do official boundaries impact on the services, representation and livelihoods that they fall on? Mike Thacker from Porism explains how to put communities back on the map, define your area and highlight community issues that can otherwise be missed

entry.title: ODI St Petersburg: bringing you what’s new in open data in Russia
entry.summary: With open data gaining momentum in Russia, the team at ODI St Petersburg – a newly formed ODI Story Node – introduce themselves and give you the latest innovations and events in the region

entry.title: Women in data: ODI series highlights issues and pioneers
entry.summary: Laura Davis, the ODI’s Head of Content and Production, outlines the case for a new content series on ‘Women in data’, and invites you to participate in its development

entry.title: Guest post: Surrey County Council on making property planning more accessible
entry.summary: When Robert Steele, Digital Platform Manager for Data Publication at Surrey County Council and a co-founder of [Surrey Digital Services](http://surreydigitalservices.github.io/), struggled to access his own local property planning information, he decided to do something about it

entry.title: Brewdog recipe release: free as in beer, not free as in speech
entry.summary: Craft brewery Brewdog has announced it will release all its recipes for free. Beer geek, homebrewer and ODI Web Developer Stuart Harrison discusses why this is a positive move, and how Brewdog can make this even better

entry.title: The ODI announces ODI Showcase winners: Out for the Count and PetaJakarta.org
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute is pleased to announce the two winners of its second ODI Showcase: [Out for the Count](http://theodi.org/blog/odi-showcase-2016-out-for-the-count), a results tracker for local elections, and [PetaJakarta.org](http://theodi.org/news/odi-showcase-2016-peta-jakarta), an open source, real-time flood map for Jakarta

entry.title: ODI Showcase 2016: Out for the Count
entry.summary: We speak with ODI Showcase winners Out for the Count about the importance of accessible information for democracy, and their plans to build a results tracker for local elections data in time for the UK's local elections on 5 May

entry.title: ODI Showcase 2016: Peta Jakarta
entry.summary: Tomas Holderness explains his winning ODI Showcase project Peta Jakarta – an open source flood map, updated by citizens with real-time flood information using social media – and how megacities can learn to respond to weather challenges

entry.title: When data is free but not open
entry.summary: The ODI’s Jeni Tennison shares her frustration in trying to access ‘free’ Land Registry property data, and explains that even when data is publicly available and free to access, restrictive licensing makes users' lives harder than it would if it was open

entry.title: When open is not enough: bringing food security data to affected communities
entry.summary: More food security data than ever is being generated by technologies and agencies. To bring order to the ‘mess’ its data had become, the World Food Programme took an open approach – paving the way to bring information to hard-to-reach communities

entry.title: Exploring human-data interaction challenges in data discovery
entry.summary: Finding and selecting data can be complicated and inconsistent. ODI PhD student Laura Koesten shares her plans to map problems within data search from a user’s perspective

entry.title: Bringing order to data search
entry.summary: Have you ever tried to find a particular piece of data about your neighbourhood? ODI PhD student Emilia Kacprzak sets out the aims of WDAqua: a project she is working on to help people find data more easily by improving how datasets can be searched

entry.title: Seven principles to help us strengthen our data infrastructure
entry.summary: Since publication, these principles have evolved into one of the [guides](http://theodi.org/guides) that we use in our work. The latest version is available for anyone to use. If you want help in using the principles then contact us at [info@theodi.org](mailto:info@theodi.org)

entry.title: Five innovations in nutrition and hydration
entry.summary: To mark [nutrition and hydration week](http://nutritionandhydrationweek.co.uk/), we asked you for top data innovations in nutrition and hydration. Examples came from around the world, from obesity monitoring to promoting yoghurt’s health benefits

entry.title: Guest post: Europe’s one-stop shop for public sector information is on the move
entry.summary: The ePSI platform has come to an end and the European Data Portal is continuing what it started ten years ago: shaping and informing Europe's open data community

entry.title: Budget 2016: The UK must take every opportunity to strengthen data infrastructure
entry.summary: In response this week’s UK budget announcement, the ODI welcomes the commitment to building an open address register but warns that if the UK government privatises the Land Registry it needs to learn from past mistakes and not lose control over land data

entry.title: Smart cities: from buzzword to transformative implementation
entry.summary: Graduate student Katherine Tobias shares how the ODI’s [Open Data for Smart Cities](http://theodi.org/courses/open-data-for-smart-cities) course helped her look beyond tech to citizens' roles in city design and governance

entry.title: Making open source code easier with Henry
entry.summary: Along with technology to help open data publication, the ODI Labs team work on tools to help make open source code publication easier. ODI web developer Stuart Harrison introduces 'Henry', a tool to help you deploy Ruby gems faster and more frequently

entry.title: Top tips: how to create a successful startup
entry.summary: Would you love to start a business, but have no idea where to begin? Yodit Stanton set up [OpenSensors](https://www.opensensors.io/ "OpenSensors") to find solutions for her daughter's asthma, and offers her tips for budding entrepreneurs

entry.title: São Paulo open data leader: ‘Transparency should mean letting citizens shape policy’
entry.summary: As part of a series on open data leaders, we speak with Fernanda Capagnucci, Head of Integrity at São Paulo City Hall and [Open Data Leaders’ Network](http://theodi.org/open-data-leaders-network) member about her role, what drives her and the challenges of promoting transparency in Brazil

entry.title: Open data leaders: ODI publishes method paper on how to create and sustain peer networks
entry.summary: In the wake of the third cohort of open data leaders visiting the ODI for a week of peer-learning as part of the [Open Data Leaders' Network](http://theodi.org/open-data-leaders-network), the ODI has published a [method report](http://theodi.org/method-report-how-to-create-and-sustain-peer-networks-for-open-data-leaders) on how to use peer networks to develop open data leadership

entry.title: Bringing together privacy and openness: the ODI shares draft personal data principles
entry.summary: Since publication, these principles have evolved into one of the [guides](http://theodi.org/guides) that we use in our work. The latest version is available for anyone to use. If you want help in using the principles then contact us at [info@theodi.org](mailto:info@theodi.org)

entry.title: Widening the debate on data sharing
entry.summary: With the UK Government's data sharing consultation published this week, the ODI summarises it to make it more accessible and help widen the debate on data sharing

entry.title: FinTech week 2016: UK primed to be world leader in open banking
entry.summary: UK FinTech is thriving, but to remain competitive it must build on recent progress made in setting the Open Banking Standard, investigate blockchain technology, and strengthen the data infrastructure that underpins open innovation

entry.title: Global open data leaders: what a year of peer-learning looks like
entry.summary: Having welcomed nine open data leaders from around the world to London for a week of peer-learning as part of the [Open Data Leaders’ Network](http://theodi.org/open-data-leaders-network), Dawn Duhaney reflects on what the programme has achieved in the year since it began

entry.title: Win two places on an open data course at the ODI
entry.summary: We’ve all heard of data, and most of us understand what it is and why it’s important. But what about ‘open’ data? Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It helps us to share information and knowledge more easily, and it’s changing the way we do business, progress medical research, understand our environment and much, much more.

entry.title: What is a data scientist? ODI Trainer Dr Dave Tarrant answers our questions
entry.summary: Last year the ODI launched a new course, [‘Open Data Science’](http://theodi.org/courses/open-data-science), as part of the [European Data Science Academy](http://edsa-project.eu) project. ODI Trainer and Data Scientist Dr [Dave Tarrant](http://theodi.org/team/david-tarrant) shares why data science skills are crucial in the modern world

entry.title: Family food survey data: How British diets have changed since 1974
European Data Portal: bringing open data’s economic benefits to public bodies
entry.summary: In line with the launch of its [official site](http://www.europeandataportal.eu/), the EDP is gathering stories and economic insights to bring to public bodies who could benefit more from open data

entry.title: Open data knots and how to escape them
entry.summary: Drawing on poems by R. D. Laing, ODI Technical Director Jeni Tennison explores ‘knots’ that open data owners and users can get trapped in when they don’t take time to develop a common language, build trust and identify shared goals

entry.title: Guest post: Making gazette notices standard and comparable
entry.summary: Following the launch of [OpenGazettes](http://blog.opencorporates.com/2015/12/01/opengazettes-digitising-government-gazettes-for-a-data-driven-age/), a new project that will make the information in government gazettes more accessible, OpenCorporates share how they plan to store information for gazette notices with a schema

entry.title: Comment: ‘Transparent governments publish open data: Fifa should be no exception’
entry.summary: Ahead of Fifa’s [presidential election](http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-32920191 "presidential election") ODI Commercial Writer Jack Hardinges reiterates the role open data could play in bringing about a new era of transparency

entry.title: UK Open Banking Working Group publishes report setting out Open Banking Standard
entry.summary: Open Banking Working Group report calls for new standard to improve choice for customers, create more competition and stimulate innovation in banking

entry.title: ODI Node update: Building a sustainable network for open innovation around the world
entry.summary: The ODI Node network has evolved. Following a period of intensive experimentation and growth, we reflect on lessons learned and how we have developed our focus for the network for 2016

entry.title: Data Privacy Day: can we stop informed consent from being an illusion?
entry.summary: Do you feel that you have control over how your data is shared and used? Do you give informed consent or do you feel resigned to giving up your data? This [Data Privacy Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DataPrivacyDay), Peter Wells explains what we can all do to help make consent more informed

entry.title: Open Data Certificate: revamped to boost data publishing standards around the world
entry.summary: Open Data Certificate achieves over 150,000 published certificates, introduces an auto-certification process and revamps badge levels to encourage publishing standards worldwide

entry.title: Blockchains: ODI and Digital Catapult respond to Blackett review on Distributed Ledger Technology
entry.summary: The [Digital Catapult](https://digital.catapult.org.uk/) and [Open Data Institute](http://theodi.org) welcome the Government Office for Science’s [Distributed Ledger Technolog](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/distributed-ledger-technology-blackett-review)[y: Blackett Review](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/distributed-ledger-technology-blackett-review) published today. And together, have issued a [joint response](https://www.scribd.com/doc/295966255/Digital-Catapult-and-Open-Data-Institute-Response-to-the-Government-Chief-Scientific-Advisor-s-report-on-distributed-ledger-technologies) to the report expressing a shared perspective (viewable in full below).

entry.title: Comment: Blockchain technology is useful, but not for everything
entry.summary: The Government Chief Scientific Advisor is exploring blockchain technologies. We welcome the focus on data infrastructure but call for more scrutiny of risks, less hype and a focus on using blockchains to solve challenges

entry.title: Blockchain and open data: how could it work?
entry.summary: Stuart Harrison discusses the ODI Labs team's foray into putting open data into a blockchain – and what would happen if they opened it up to miners

entry.title: A year in open data: How Visualising Rail Disruption helped commuters avoid delays
entry.summary: With commuters across Britain complaining of poor morning rail service, the ODI and startup Fasteroute decided to investigate. They found that by making small changes to their travel patterns, people could avoid up to a day of delays per year

entry.title: Caution: data, use responsibly
entry.summary: Should open data be published with guidelines on its use and limits? Senior Consultant Leigh Dodds thinks so, and draws on Open Prescribing to explain why

entry.title: Help us find valuable data for agriculture
entry.summary: Contribute to our list of different types, sources and examples of data related to agriculture, and help us develop a better understanding of data in the sector

entry.title: What would legislation for data infrastructure and open data look like?
entry.summary: Given the importance of data infrastructure, countries should be looking to [strengthen it](http://theodi.org/blog/an-open-letter-to-the-chair-of-the-new-infrastructure-commission "strengthen it"). One of the ways that countries can strengthen their data infrastructure is through legislation.

entry.title: ODI Futures: How open innovation will transform agriculture
entry.summary: On 3 December we held an event focusing on the future of agriculture, in partnership with the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. Chaired by ODI Head of Research Dr Tom Heath, it gathered stakeholders in the sector to explore data-driven innovation, with a focus on open data.

entry.title: Member blog: Data and a more sustainable future
entry.summary: ODI Member SAP reveals the challenges and opportunities in open data

entry.title: Kicking Aruba into a bin
entry.summary: ODI Head of Robots Sam Pikesley uncovers some new features in Rspec in his search for alternative tools for building Ruby command-line interface apps

entry.title: Are you our next ODI associate?
entry.summary: The ODI Services team launches a call for applications from world-class experts to become ODI associates

entry.title: A year in open data: How the ODI helped to deliver a successful democratic transition in Burkina Faso
entry.summary: At the ODI, we work with external partners to shape, create and promote the social, environmental and economic benefits that open data can bring to different communities and sectors around the world.

entry.title: Amanda Smith wins Bloomberg Open Technology Award
entry.summary: Last month Amanda Smith, formerly ODI Community Engagement Manager and now ODI Account Manager, won the Bloomberg Open Technology Award, a WISE Award for female role models making a difference in open source communities

entry.title: A year in open data: Breathe Heathrow informs policy making
entry.summary: Access to data can bring objectivity and insight to highly polarised debates. By involving communities in collecting and publishing data, OpenSensors.io and the ODI demonstrated how both citizens and policy makers can become better informed about issues of local and national importance

entry.title: A year in open data: Open data means business in 2015
entry.summary: Across the UK, we found 270 businesses, from tech startups to bricks-and-mortar retailers, which are unlocking value by using, publishing and investing in open data. Collectively, these companies employ half a million people and generate more than £92bn in annual revenue

entry.title: Paris climate agreement: betting on an ocean of data-led innovation
entry.summary: In the wake of the Paris climate agreement, Mark Harvey from ODI Member Resurgence explains why open data-based approaches will be vital in implementing it and monitoring its progress towards global targets

entry.title: A year in open data: Delivering on the early promise of the Open Data Challenge Series
entry.summary: From a personalised careers service to an app for house hunters showing the proximity of local amenities, the Open Data Challenge Series delivered on its promise to bring new ideas to market that provide social, environmental and economic impact

entry.title: Alex McLean chosen as the first Open Data Institute sound artist in residence
A year in open data: How ODI paved the way for a stronger data infrastructure in 2015
entry.summary: At the ODI, we work with external partners to shape, create and promote the social, environmental and economic benefits that open data can bring to different communities and sectors around the world.

entry.title: Travel smarter with open data app Fasteroute
entry.summary: Research from open data startup [Fasteroute](http://fasteroute.com) and the [Open Data Institute](http://theodi.org) (ODI) reveals the UK cities most affected by morning delays and how commuters can avoid them

entry.title: How can blockchains evolve?
entry.summary: Blockchains are a distributed append-only way of storing data. They are reliant on a large network for their maintenance, and can only grow in size. Jeni Tennison, the ODI’s Technical Director, looks at scenarios for how blockchains might evolve over time

entry.title: Are blockchains the right choice for global data infrastructure?
An open letter to the Chair of the new Infrastructure Commission
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute and Royal Statistical Society urge Lord Adonis and the Infrastructure Commission to consider data as infrastructure that is fundamental to the operation of a modern society and its economy

entry.title: Open Data Leaders Network: an open call for outstanding government leaders
entry.summary: The Open Data Leaders Network (ODLN) programme calls for exceptional global leaders of open data initiatives worldwide, to take part in its 6-month programme in 2016-17

entry.title: How can open data help bridge the digital language divide?
entry.summary: Over half of the landing pages of the web’s most visited sites are written in English. In light of ‘information inequality’ online, Alexander Leon explores how open data can help improve the web for non-English speakers

entry.title: ODI features in full force at Big Bang Data art exhibition
entry.summary: The ODI affirms its commitment to data and the arts, showcasing artworks, thought-leadership and training at the heart of London’s cultural scene

entry.title: ODI Futures: Who owns open agricultural data?
entry.summary: In the run-up to our ODI Futures [event](https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/myevent?eid=19081924550) on Agriculture in partnership with Defra, we asked CABI’s Martin Parr to share his thoughts on how data can be used in agriculture, along with the benefits, and challenges, that come with opening it up

entry.title: ODI Futures: Why linked open data can help boost stifled innovation in agronomics
entry.summary: In the run-up to our ODI Futures [event](https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/myevent?eid=19081924550) on agriculture, in partnership with Defra, Robert Allen, event panelist and co-chair of Agri-Tech East’s ‘big data’ group talks about the role open data can play in improving agronomic understanding of crop performance

entry.title: Open Banking Working Group panel to discuss improving banking services
entry.summary: Today in ['A better deal: boosting competition to bring down bills for families and firms'](http://www.example.com "'A better deal: boosting competition to bring down bills for families and firms'"), the UK Government confirmed that it is committed to providing an open API standard in UK banking.

entry.title: Playing with data: our ODI open data board game
entry.summary: For the last six months, on and off, a few of us here at the Open Data Institute have been working on an open data board game. Ellen Broad and Jeni Tennision discuss its development

entry.title: ODI Futures: How can open data improve farmers’ choices?
entry.summary: In April 2015, agriculture company Syngenta published its first open datasets as part of [The Good Growth Plan](http://www.syngenta.com/global/corporate/en/goodgrowthplan/home/Pages/homepage.aspx), with a view to improving global resource efficiency, soil and biodiversity conservation, and the prosperity of small farms in developing countries. But can open data really help to solve our world food crisis?

entry.title: Invitation to tender: ODINE website redesign and development
entry.summary: This is a call for tenders by the Open Data Institute for the Open Data Incubator for Europe (ODINE).

entry.title: Response to spending review: Government should strengthen UK data infrastructure
entry.summary: ODI Technical Director Jeni Tennison welcomes investments in digital innovation, and calls on government to not lose sight of the need for a strong data infrastructure

entry.title: How we made the ODI’s award-winning annual report
entry.summary: Having picked up the award for best annual report with her team at the CorpComms ceremony last night, ODI Writer and Editor Anna Scott reflects on the ideas, creativity, people and trust that helped make it happen

entry.title: Work with us to explore the economic value of core data assets
entry.summary: The Open Data Institute (ODI) connects, equips and inspires people around the world to innovate with data. It is independent, non-profit and non-partisan, founded in 2012 by Sir Tim Berners-Lee and Sir Nigel Shadbolt. The ODI is based in London and its node network operates in 20 countries across six continents.

Guest post: How Open Results Based Financing is creating trust and transparency in Burundi
entry.summary: Results-based financing (RBF) emerged as a key part of the “aid effectiveness” agenda in development financing. It is an approach that helps build resilient and sustainable public services where payments are made based on specified outcomes that can be proven to have taken place according to a set of measurable indicators. These indicators are verified and validated on a monthly or quarterly basis by external verifiers and local communities who provide independent feedback through interviews and mobile devices. [Cordaid](https://www.cordaid.org/en/) pioneered RBF for health in Sub-Saharan Africa and is at present involved in RBF programs in 13 countries in healthcare and education.

entry.title: Taking new drugs to a global market: what role can open data play?
Project managers for civic tech. We need them. (Is this you?)
entry.summary: In your life and work, you probably know the kind of people that get stuff done. The closers. The owners. The people who send gentle reminders and nudges. They exist everywhere – in all sectors of work, in life, in family. They follow up on things until they get done. They schedule. They are human glue. Without their keep-it-togetherness, projects trail off into dead email threads that began with the best intentions. The civic tech community needs these people. Badly.

entry.title: New online course launched to widen data anonymisation skills
entry.summary: Keeping personal data separate from open data is a core principle to protect people from harm. Anonymisation is an effective process to manage the release of data that is derived from individuals. At present, guidance for anonymising data is sparse and unclear. This restricts important information from being released safely that others can benefit from.

entry.title: OpenDataMonitor gathers over 500 open data resources
entry.summary: From the beginning of the open data movement, proponents of the cause have been gathering evidence to demonstrate the economic, social and environmental value of open data. entry.title: Open Data Barometer: how did Arab countries perform? (part 2)
entry.summary: The [World Wide Web Foundation](http://webfoundation.org/) has released the 2015 edition of its [Open Data Barometer](http://opendatabarometer.org/) – a report that aims to uncover the true prevalence and impact of government open data initiatives around the world. In the second part of this [two-part](http://theodi.org/blog/the-open-data-barometer-a-review-of-the-arab-countries-performance-1of2) blog post we take a closer look at the Arab region. We'll take a look at how it has been progressing on not just open data awareness, but also implementation and more concrete evidence of progress.

entry.title: 5 ways to be a better open data reuser
entry.summary: Open data is still in its infancy. The focus so far has been on encouraging and supporting owners of data to publish it openly. A lot has been written about why opening up data is valuable, [how to build business cases](http://theodi.org/guides/how-make-business-case-open-data) for open data sharing, and [how to publish data](http://theodi.org/guides/engaging-reusers) in order to make it easy for people to reuse.

entry.title: Standard launched to ensure transparency and efficiency in contracting
entry.summary: The world’s first [Open Contracting Data Standard](http://standard.open-contracting.org/) (OCDS) was launched in Costa Rica today (November 18th, 2014) and is set to transform the way governments publish contracting data. The OCDS is a product of the [Open Contracting Partnership](http://www.open-contracting.org/) (OCP), developed by the [World Wide Web Foundation](http://webfoundation.org/) through a project supported by the [Omidyar Network](http://www.omidyar.com/) and the [World Bank](http://www.worldbank.org/). It will shine a light on how trillions of dollars of public money are spent, helping to fight corruption, improve service delivery and enhance market efficiency.

entry.title: 25 years of the web: open data, open innovation

entry.title: Environmental and economic impact of UK government spending revealed by ODI supporter AMEE and ODI startup Spend Network
entry.summary: [New research](https://www.amee.com/government-departments) by AMEE, a company that helps businesses become more energy efficient, and [Spend Network](https://spendnetwork.com/), which analyses government procurement, shows more than £844m was spent on high financial risk companies by central government in 2013/14. The analysis, using open spending data, also shows wide variations in carbon efficiency - over the same period, £4.6bn was spent with companies who have low energy and carbon efficiency (when compared to better-performing peers). AMEE is an [ODI supporter](https://directory.theodi.org/members/GY5132UY) and Spend Network is a member of the [ODI startup programme](http://theodi.org/start-ups).

entry.title: Latin American legislatures lack transparency and open data
entry.summary: Recently, the second edition of the [Latin American Index of Legislative Transparency](http://indice2014.transparencialegislativa.org/ "Latin American Index of Legislative Transparency") was launched in the Senate of Argentina. It has been designed to assess the legislatures of Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guatemala, Mexico, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela. In the latest measurements the average country score fell below 40%. Peru and Chile head the table with ratings of just above 50%.

entry.title: Send us your feedback: How open data can improve UK public procurement
entry.summary: The UK Government is [consulting](https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachmentdata/file/364181/ConsultationonSBEEBill.pdf "link to consultation") on how small businesses could gain better access to public sector contract opportunities, through a new power contained in the Small Business, Enterprise and Employment (SBEE) Bill. The ODI has [drafted a short submission](https://docs.google.com/a/theodi.org/document/d/1N758j2erzt8pmn-O7JW9SwVzvbKvTkzfBdJPrYGtBrQ/editheading=h.ceesugyrhp6a) to the consultation that's accessible [here](https://docs.google.com/a/theodi.org/document/d/1N758j2erzt8pmn-O7JW9SwVzvbKvTkzfBdJPrYGtBrQ/editheading=h.ceesugyrhp6a" ODI draft procurement submission"), and we're interested in your feedback on our draft.

entry.title: ODI, UUK and top UK universities launch project to unlock open data potential in higher education
entry.summary: The ODI and [Universities UK](http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx), have today (4th November) announced that they will lead a project involving a group of top UK universities, the [National Union of Students (NUS)](http://www.nus.org.uk/) and [Jisc](http://www.jisc.ac.uk/) to explore the opportunities open data presents the higher education (HE) sector in the UK. The project is called “Creating Value from Open Data”.

entry.title: £383k government grant released to create UK open address list
entry.summary: The ODI announced today that a grant from the UK Cabinet Office’s Release of Data Fund has been released to create a UK open address list as an alternative to other address databases available in the UK. The open address list will bring together information about the places where people live, work and visit. By gathering information provided directly by people about addresses they know, and from open data sources, it will grow into an open address list for the UK, available to everyone as open data.

entry.title: Developing an open data maturity model
entry.summary: Organisational change is an important aspect of becoming an open data publisher. Often the technical process of getting data published is actually the easiest step. But if users are to have reliable, ongoing access to data then organisations need to consider the strategic, financial and operational impacts of making their open data publishing efforts sustainable.

entry.title: Climate change: 4 ways to protect cities with open data

Grocery shops pile fruit on stalls outside their doors, while a barmaid pours water outside a nearby pub and offers a leftover sandwich to a homeless man.

entry.title: New open data powered platform for community energy groups
entry.summary: Today we are pleased to announce the winner of our Energy and Environment Open Data Challenge as Community Energy Manager, a service for community energy groups developed by Matthew Wood and Mark Corbin. Community Energy Manager (CEM) is an online tool that helps community groups to support their local area by facilitating large scale retrofit projects and bulk purchasing. CEM will help groups to develop into viable social enterprises with regular income streams.

entry.title: Open Addresses: Discovery Phase
entry.summary: Geospatial data underpins practically everything, because everything happens somewhere. A lot of things happen somewhere with an address: our schools, hospitals, museums, supermarkets, places of work, homes. So address data — data about what addresses exist and where they are — is an essential underpinning for our national information infrastructure.

entry.title: Guest post: A step forward for democratic engagement
entry.summary: Even after the local council elections in England and Northern Ireland on 22 May, which coincided with polling for the European Parliament, the next 12 months remain a busy time for the democratic process in the United Kingdom. In September, the people of Scotland make their choice in a referendum on the future of the Union. Finally, the first fixed-term parliament in Westminster comes to an end with a General Election in all areas of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in May 2015.
